page.title: 04THE EDEN ESTUARY
page.content: A nature reserve was established in June 1984 at the mouth of the River Eden to protect its ecology. At high tide Flounders, Eider Ducks and Shelducks, feed on Lugworms, Cockles, Mussels, Shrimps and Snails. When the mudflats are exposed, they provide a feeding ground for wading birds; e.g. Godwits, Oyster Catchers and Plovers. Many migrant wading birds visit the area and in winter there are about 60 seals. In spring, there are about 20 swans. On the Western fringe of the estuary in the saltmarshes grows a yellow-centred lilac flower called Sea Aster, which attracts insects. Seaward of this, grows a cactus-like plant called Glasswort, which traps silt to build a new saltmarsh. Cord Grass planted in 1948 has spread onto the mudflats, smothering the flora.
